subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... Then don t use setUp() :-) ... If all your testMethods() use the same environment (the same setup), you can remove duplication by moving the common set up
messageBody:
On Thursday 26 May 2005 10:21, alpanhell wrote:
> in all my TestCase's I'm
> creating I'm finding no place where I need the same setup and teardown
> before every test within that TestCase.

Then don't use setUp() :-)

> I can't think of very many scenarios where this would be useful,

If all your testMethods() use the same environment (the same setup), you
can remove duplication by moving the common set up code into setUp().
Example

public class FooTest extens TestCase {
public void testFooA() {
Foo fooUnderTest = new Foo();
foo.enterKnownStateForTest();
foo.doA();
assertTrue(foo.getResultA());
}

public void testFooB() {
Foo fooUnderTest = new Foo();
foo.enterKnownStateForTest();
foo.doB();
assertTrue(foo.getResultB());
}
}

Here you can make fooUnderTest a member in the test class and move the
first two lines of each method to setUp():

public class FooTest extens TestCase {
private Foo foo;

public void setUp() {
fooUnderTest = new Foo();
foo.enterKnownStateForTest();
}

public void testFooA() {
foo.doA();
assertTrue(foo.getResultA());
}

public void testFooB() {
foo.doB();
assertTrue(foo.getResultB());
}
}


> yet I'm finding tons of places
> where I need a one time setup and teardown for the whole TestCase.

Are your tests really independent from each other?

Robert
